newsitem.title: USA: GM sees continued N. American profit growth.
newsitem.headline: GM sees continued N. American profit growth.

text.p: General Motors Corp said Friday it expects its North American Operations to continue to show improved profitability in 1997.

"For the remainder of 1997, we expect our North American Operations to continue showing the kind of progress demonstrated in its highly profitable first quarter," GM Chairman John Smith Jr said in a statement released from Wilmington, where GM is holding its annual meeting.
GM's North American Operations reported net income of $764 million for the first quarter -- the best performance in more than a decade.
Sales of GM vehicles outside North America totaled 3.1 million vehicles in 1996 -- about 37 percent of GM's total worldwide sales.
Smith said five new manufacturing complexes are under construction -- in Argentina, Brazil, Poland, Thailand and China. He said Thailand and China are keys to markets in Asia.

Last week GM received a business license for its $1.6 billion deal to build Buick midsize cars in China. The company said it is also negotiating with Chinese officials for joint ventures to produce engines, Opel cars and light-duty trucks.

"We project that half of all our new-vehicle sales will come from outside North America shortly after the turn of the century," Smith said, citing the International Monetary Fund's projection that the world economy is now set to grow at the fastest rate in more than a decade.
Smith also told stockholders that GM expects to present to shareholders later this year a proposal to spin off the defense business of its Hughes Electronics Corp subsidiary.

He also said GM's Delphi Automotive Systems continues grow business outside the North American Operations vehicle groups, and is on track to meet its goal of 50 percent non-GM-North American Operations sales by the end of the year 2002.
"General Motors intends to become a growth company once again," Smith said.
